The social aspect of tennis is a huge part of the game's appeal! Meeting new people and building relationships with fellow tennis enthusiasts can make the experience even more enjoyable. It's great that you're finding a sense of community at the tennis club.

The mental challenge of improving your technique and strategy is also a significant part of the game. It's awesome that you're embracing the process and working on your backhand with your instructor. Improving your technique takes time and practice, but it's rewarding to see progress and feel more confident on the court.

Remember, it's normal to struggle with certain shots or techniques, especially when you're starting out. The key is to be patient, persistent, and kind to yourself as you work through the challenges. Your instructor is there to help you improve, so don't hesitate to ask questions or seek feedback.

As you continue to work on your backhand, you might find it helpful to break it down into smaller components, focus on one aspect at a time, and practice regularly. You can also try recording yourself playing to identify areas for improvement or to track your progress over time.

Keep in mind that tennis is a game of inches, and even small improvements can make a big difference in your overall game. Don't be too hard on yourself if you don't see immediate results – every shot you take is an opportunity to learn and improve.

How's your instructor's teaching style? Are they providing helpful tips and feedback, or is there anything you'd like to work on with them?
